metadata.description: Middle school admissions evaluation criteria - v2 sophisticated assessment
metadata.critical_context: These are 10-12 year old children. Expectations must be age-appropriate. Schools look for POTENTIAL, not polish.

evaluation_philosophy.core_principle: At this age, authenticity trumps achievement. A genuine, enthusiastic child with room to grow beats a polished applicant who sounds like an adult.
what_matters_most: Does the application sound like a child wrote it?
Is there genuine enthusiasm and curiosity visible?
Does the child have at least one sustained interest (2+ years)?
Do parents show realistic understanding of their child?
Is there evidence of potential and growth mindset?

harker.name: Harker Middle School
what_they_seek: Intellectual curiosity and love of learning
Well-rounded students who can thrive in challenging environment
harker.academic_expectations: Strong academics across subjects, particularly in core areas
harker.special_notes: Interview is important - they want engaged, curious students who can articulate their interests

nueva.name: Nueva School
what_they_seek: Love of learning for its own sake
nueva.academic_expectations: Gifted-level testing required; looking for asynchronous development
nueva.special_notes: Creative project is CRUCIAL - must show authentic student work. Social-emotional development valued alongside academics.

crystal_springs.name: Crystal Springs Uplands
crystal_springs.academic_expectations: Solid academic foundation with room for growth
crystal_springs.special_notes: Small, close-knit community. Interview matters a lot.

menlo.name: Menlo School
menlo.academic_expectations: Competitive academics with evidence of challenge-seeking
menlo.special_notes: Video responses (Kira) are part of evaluation

basis.name: BASIS Independent
basis.academic_expectations: Entrance exam is key factor; must demonstrate readiness for advanced work
basis.special_notes: Less emphasis on essays, more on demonstrated academic ability

Genuine hobby they pursue on their own
One notable achievement at local/regional level

Some evidence of growth or progression

high_priority.name: Essay Sounds Adult-Written
high_priority.description: The biggest red flag in middle school admissions. Schools detect this immediately.
high_priority.counselor_explanation: This essay doesn't sound like an 11-year-old wrote it. Private school admissions officers read thousands of essays and can immediately tell when a parent or consultant has written or heavily edited a child's work. This is one of the most damaging things in an application.

high_priority.name: Over-Scheduled Child
high_priority.description: 10+ activities at age 10 is a red flag, not a strength
high_priority.counselor_explanation: This activity list suggests an over-scheduled child. Selective middle schools want to see depth and genuine passion, not a long list of everything you've ever tried. At this age, quality matters far more than quantity.

high_priority.name: No Child Personality Visible
high_priority.description: The application feels like a checklist, not a child
detection_signals: Could apply to any child with minor changes
high_priority.counselor_explanation: After reading this application, I can't picture who this child actually is. There's no personality, no specific moments, no genuine enthusiasm. Admissions officers want to meet a real child through the applicationâ€”not a resume.

medium_priority.name: Achievements Sound Inflated
medium_priority.description: Claims that seem disproportionate for a 10-11 year old
medium_priority.counselor_explanation: Some achievements described here seem unusually advanced for a 5th grader. Admissions officers are skeptical of inflated claims and prefer honest, age-appropriate accomplishments.

medium_priority.name: Parent Statement Doesn't Match Child
medium_priority.description: Disconnect between what child and parent describe
medium_priority.counselor_explanation: The parent statement doesn't align with what the child wrote. This disconnect suggests either lack of authenticity or a parent who's projecting their aspirations rather than describing their actual child.

the_curious_explorer.description: Loves learning across many areas, asks lots of questions

the_dedicated_practitioner.description: Deep commitment to one or two activities with clear growth

the_kind_connector.description: Shows empathy, helps others, values relationships

the_resilient_learner.description: Has faced challenges and grown from them

output_notes.tone: Encouraging but honest. These are children - be kind but truthful.
output_notes.format: Identify weaknesses but frame appropriately for a family with a 10-12 year old.
output_notes.remember: Potential over polish. Schools want to see who this child might become, not a finished product.
